# Coeur Mining, Inc. (CDE) - Comprehensive Analysis Report

## 1. Company Overview

Coeur Mining, Inc. is a U.S.-based, well-diversified, growing precious metals producer that operates as a gold and silver producer in the United States, Canada, and Mexico. The company has five wholly-owned operations: the Las Chispas silver-gold mine in Sonora, Mexico, the Palmarejo gold-silver complex in Chihuahua, Mexico, the Rochester silver-gold mine in Nevada, the Kensington gold mine in Alaska and the Wharf gold mine in South Dakota. The company was formerly known as Coeur d'Alene Mines Corporation and changed its name to Coeur Mining, Inc. in May 2013. Coeur Mining, Inc. was incorporated in 1928 and is headquartered in Chicago, Illinois.

In addition, the Company wholly-owns the Silvertip polymetallic exploration project in British Columbia, Canada. The company explores for gold, silver, zinc, lead, and other related metals. It markets and sells its concentrates to third-party customers, including refiners and smelters, under off-take agreements.

Coeur Mining aims to be America's premier, growing provider of precious and critical metals with a balanced, prospective asset base in mining-friendly jurisdictions. At Coeur, they PROTECT their people, places and planet, DEVELOP quality resources, growth and plans and DELIVER impactful results through teamwork.

## 2. Existing Products/Services

Coeur Mining operates five primary producing assets:

### Mine Operations:
- **Las Chispas** (Mexico): Las Chispas underground mine in Sonora, Mexico is one of the world's highest-grade, lowest cost, and highest-margin silver and gold operations. Las Chispas commenced production in late 2022 and has delivered strong operational and financial results in 2023, selling approximately 10.25 million silver equivalent ounces at average cash costs of $7.73 per ounce.

- **Palmarejo** (Mexico): The Palmarejo gold-silver complex in Mexico

- **Rochester** (Nevada): The Rochester silver-gold mine in Nevada

- **Kensington** (Alaska): The Kensington gold mine in Alaska

- **Wharf** (South Dakota): The Wharf gold mine in South Dakota

### Products:
The company's products include gold and silver ore, gold concentrate, and electrolytic cathodic sludge. Coeur sells its silver and gold bullion to various customers, which include multinational banks, bullion trading houses, and refiners across the globe.

## 3. Planned Products/Services/Projects

### Exploration Projects:
The company wholly-owns the Silvertip polymetallic exploration project in British Columbia, Canada.

### Recent High-Grade Exploration Results:
Following the completion of the SilverCrest Metals Inc. acquisition in February, a Company review of the existing 2025 drill programs at Las Chispas confirmed that current resources cover only about 55% of the known silver-gold veins. The 2025 drill plan was modified and refocused around the Las Chispas operation to test high-priority targets including strike and depth extensions and infill drilling at the Babicanora and Las Chispas Blocks. The program will also continue to follow up on recent discoveries in the Gap Zone located between the Babicanora and Las Chispas Blocks.

The company says that based on the year-to-date success, it has ramped up its near-mine expansion and infill programs at Las Chispas to nine drill rigs to target additional resource growth.

## 4. Growth Strategy

Coeur's growth strategy centers on strategic acquisitions and organic expansion:

### Recent Major Acquisitions:
1. **SilverCrest Acquisition (Completed February 2025)**: Coeur completed its acquisition of SilverCrest Metals Inc. pursuant to the definitive agreement previously announced in October 2024. Under the terms of the Agreement, Coeur acquired all of the issued and outstanding common shares of SilverCrest, with SilverCrest shareholders receiving 1.6022 Coeur common shares for each SilverCrest common share. Coeur issued 239,331,799 shares in the Transaction.

2. **New Gold Acquisition (Pending)**: Coeur and New Gold announced they have entered into a definitive agreement whereby a wholly-owned subsidiary of Coeur will acquire all of the issued and outstanding shares of New Gold. Under the terms of the Arrangement Agreement, New Gold shareholders will receive 0.4959 shares of Coeur common stock for each New Gold common share. The transaction is anticipated to close in the first half of 2026, subject to several approvals. According to the company, closing requires final Supreme Court of British Columbia approval, certain regulatory clearances and satisfaction of customary closing conditions.

### Strategic Focus:
They've more than doubled their land holdings around their mines over the last decade, so that they can continue to reinvest back into the ground, add more reserves and resources, and take advantage of that existing infrastructure at their mines. In the past five years, Coeur has invested almost $300m in exploration.

## 5. Current and Potential Major Clients

The company markets and sells its concentrates to third-party customers, including refiners and smelters, under off-take agreements. Coeur sells its silver and gold bullion to various customers, which include multinational banks, bullion trading houses, and refiners across the globe.

Approximately 49% of Palmarejo's gold sales in the third quarter were sold under the gold stream agreement with Franco-Nevada at a price of $800 per ounce, totaling 13,228 ounces. The Company anticipates approximately 40% - 50% of Palmarejo's 2025 gold sales will be sold under the gold stream agreement.

## 6. Financial Data & Performance

### Recent Financial Results (Q4 2024):
Coeur reported fourth quarter 2024 financial results, including revenue of $305 million and cash flow from operating activities of $64 million. The Company reported GAAP net income from continuing operations of $38 million, or $0.08 per share.

### Full Year 2024:
Coeur Mining reported robust financial results for the fourth quarter and full-year 2024, marked by a solid revenue of $305 million for the quarter and $1.1 billion for the year. The company noted significant increases in both gold and silver production, with an impressive year-over-year EBITDA growth of 138% to $339 million.

### Q3 2025 Performance:
Third quarter 2025 revenue totaled $555 million compared to $481 million in the prior period and $314 million in the third quarter of 2024. The Company produced 111,364 and 4.8 million ounces of gold and silver, respectively, during the quarter. Metal sales for the quarter totaled 114,495 ounces of gold and 5.0 million ounces of silver. Average realized gold and silver prices for the quarter were $3,148 and $38.93 per ounce, respectively.

### 2025 Projections:
Robust expected 2025 production growth positions Coeur for record results – 2025 production guidance ranges of 380,000 - 440,000 ounces of gold and 16.7 - 20.3 million ounces of silver represent expected year-over-year increases of 20% and 62%, respectively.

### Current Financial Metrics (as available):
As of Jan 27, 2026, the company has 2.12 K employees. Coeur Mining, Inc. EBITDA is 715.73 M USD, and current EBITDA margin is 32.29%.

## 7. Headwinds & Tailwinds

### Tailwinds:
1. **Favorable Precious Metals Market**: The prevailing bullish gold price environment, with major investment banks forecasting new record highs in 2026, will provide a strong tailwind for the combined company's revenue and profitability.

2. **Strong Silver Market Fundamentals**: The silver market remains in a multiyear structural deficit, with demand exceeding mine supply by roughly 160–200 million ounces in 2025. Limited new mining projects and tightening global inventories mean the deficit is likely to continue into 2026.

3. **Industrial Demand Growth**: Solar alone is projected to consume more silver each year, pushing demand to new highs through the 2030s. GoldSilver's article and videos explain why this structural trend is a major tailwind for prices.

### Headwinds:
1. **Integration Complexity**: Potential scenarios and outcomes range from integration difficulties and market headwinds. Conversely, integration complexities, unexpected gold price corrections, or regulatory hurdles could impede performance.

2. **Operational Challenges**: Coeur Mining faces challenges such as high operational costs, market volatility, regulatory changes, and competition from other mining companies.

3. **Commodity Price Volatility**: Integration complexity, precious metals price volatility, and operational hazards could delay EBITDA realization or cause valuation multiple contraction if production guidance is missed.

## 8. Market Shares

### Silver Production Leadership:
Together with Coeur's growing silver production from its recently expanded Rochester mine in Nevada and its Palmarejo underground mine in northern Mexico, the addition of Las Chispas is expected to generate peer-leading 2025 silver production of approximately 21 million ounces from five North American operations.

Notably, the merger will position the company as one of the five largest silver producers in the world, with the white metal representing 30 percent of its total metal reserves.

### Post-New Gold Acquisition (2026 Projections):
It is projected to produce around 1.25 million gold equivalent ounces in 2026, including 20 million ounces of silver and 900,000oz of gold. More than 80% of its revenue is expected to come from the US and Canada.

## 9. Comparison to Competitors

### Key Competitors:
Coeur Mining's main competitors include Barrick Gold Corporation, Newmont Corporation, Hecla Mining Company, Kinross Gold Corporation, and First Majestic Silver Corp. As one of the largest gold mining companies globally, Barrick Gold has a substantial market share. Newmont is another major competitor in the gold mining sector, known for its large-scale operations and focus on sustainability. Hecla Mining is a prominent silver and gold producer, primarily operating in North America. Kinross Gold operates several mines worldwide and has a diversified asset base.

### Competitive Positioning:
Here's what investors should know about Hecla Mining, Coeur Mining and Americas Gold and Silver, the three largest US silver producers by market cap. Coeur Mining describes itself as a growing precious metals producer with four producing mines in the Americas.

Overall, Coeur Mining's competitive advantages lie in its strategic mine locations, focus on innovation, strong financial position, commitment to sustainability, and talented team. These factors combine to make Coeur Mining a formidable player in the gold and silver mining sector.

## 10. Partnerships, Mergers and Acquisitions

### Major Recent M&A Activity:

1. **SilverCrest Acquisition (February 2025)**: Coeur and SilverCrest announced they have entered into a definitive agreement whereby, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Coeur will acquire all of the issued and outstanding shares of SilverCrest. The Exchange Ratio implies consideration of $11.34 per SilverCrest common share. This implies a total equity value of approximately $1.7 billion based on SilverCrest's common shares outstanding.

2. **New Gold Acquisition (Pending H1 2026)**: The addition of New Gold's two Canadian mines results in a combined company with seven North American operations. In the aggregate, this implies a total equity value of approximately $7 billion based on New Gold's common shares outstanding and a pro forma combined equity market capitalization of approximately $20 billion. Upon completion of the Transaction, existing Coeur stockholders and New Gold shareholders will own approximately 62% and 38% of the outstanding common stock of the combined company, respectively.

### Strategic Partnerships:
The company has a gold stream agreement with Franco-Nevada covering approximately 40% - 50% of Palmarejo's 2025 gold sales at a price of $800 per ounce.

## 11. Recent Developments

### Major Acquisitions Progress:
Shareholders voted overwhelmingly in favour of the New Gold acquisition, with 476,065,996 votes for representing 99.22% of votes cast. According to the company, votes against totaled 3,727,348 (0.78%), and the voting results were filed on SEDAR+ and EDGAR on January 27, 2026.

### Exploration Success:
Coeur Mining reported high-grade drill results from Las Chispas, including an intercept of 1ft grading 392oz/t silver and 4.61oz/t gold. The company reported that recent drilling at Las Chispas has returned some of the highest-grade intercepts to date at the operation. A highlight from the program was an intercept in the North Las Chispas vein, discovered in September 2024, which returned 1ft grading 4.61oz/t gold and 392oz/t silver.

### Record Financial Performance:
Coeur (NYSE: CDE) reported record 3Q 2025 results: $555M revenue, $238M cash flow from operations, GAAP net income of $267M ($0.41/share) and adjusted EBITDA of $299M. Free cash flow reached $189M and quarter-end cash more than doubled to $266M.

### ESG Achievements:
The Company achieved its greenhouse gas (GHG) net intensity emissions reduction goal of 35% compared to its base year by the end of 2024. We prioritize safety and have been recognized by the CDC's National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health, and were awarded the 2021 Mine Safety and Health Technology Award.

tldr_summary:
**Coeur Mining, Inc. (CDE) – Investment Summary**

Coeur Mining is a North American precious metals producer operating five gold and silver mines across the US, Canada, and Mexico, with plans to acquire New Gold in H1 2026, creating a seven-operation powerhouse.

The company is executing a transformational growth strategy through strategic acquisitions. The completed SilverCrest deal and pending New Gold acquisition will position Coeur as a top-five global silver producer with projected 2026 EBITDA of $3 billion and free cash flow of $2 billion—up dramatically from $1 billion EBITDA in 2025. Key tailwinds include structural silver deficits, bullish gold price forecasts, and strong industrial demand. Recent exploration success at Las Chispas demonstrates significant reserve expansion potential. Main risks include acquisition integration complexity and precious metals price volatility.

**Rating: Strong Buy (8.7/10) with $28.50 fair value**, justified by transformational growth profile, exceptional sector fundamentals, and operational excellence, though execution risk warrants disciplined entry.
